lg.l: The miroMiro. Miro is a species of podocarp that produces bright red seeds. was laden with crimsoning berries,
The fruit of the tauraTaura. Likely tawa, a broadleaf tree that produces dark purple seeds. lay thick on the ground,
Alone in the midst of the forest primeval
The last of the sons of the Maori was found.
He gazed on the woods in their verdurous beauty,
The feather-like fronds of the fern-tree outspread
The beautiful rimosRimos. Rimu, a species of conifer distinguished by its drooping branches and patterned bark. with fringe-covered branches,
The might totaras,Totaras. Totara is the largest known species of podocarp. and sadly he said:
“O land of my fathers, Tavai Poënammu!Tavai Poënammu. Te Waipounamu, the South Island of New Zealand.
“O beautiful country! O land of my birth!
“The last of my people thou soon shalt receive me
“In thy fond embraces my own native earth!
“Ye tree that for ages have waved o’er the forest,
“And witnessed the warrior go forth in his pride,
“Ye beautiful rivers, on whose rapid waters
“The canoes of my fathers so swiftly did glide,
“Ye hills, and ye valleys, ye birds that are singing
“So sweetly and blithe in the sunshine to-day,
“I bid ye farewell in affection, and sadness,
“The last of the Maories is passing away.
“The foot of the stranger hath followed our people
“And trodden our footprints from out of the land,
“Like the wave of the sea that creeps up and effaces
“The line that the children have drawn in the sand;
“The ships of the stranger ride thick on our waters,
“The voice of the stranger—I hear it around,
“The valleys are red with his ripening harvests
“The hills with the low of his cattle resound;
“Alone I am left of a once mighty people,
“Alone! all alone!” and he smote on his breast
“Alone! all alone!” ‘twas the last word he uttered,
The last of the Maories had gone to his rest.
